name: Incident Management 101.txt - ## Incident
description: This section explains that an incident refers to any disruption or interruption in an organization's services, ranging from affecting a single user to the entire business. It is an event that requires human or automated intervention to restore the services to their full operational status as quickly as possible. An incident can be considered as anything that hinders the continuity of business operations.
use_cases: Service disruption affecting a single user
Service disruption affecting the entire business
Restoring services to full operational status

name: Incident Management 101.txt - ## Goal
description: This section outlines the primary objective of the Incident Management process, which is to restore normal service operations as quickly as possible while minimizing the adverse impact on business operations and ensuring agreed service quality levels are maintained. It emphasizes the importance of using standardized methods and procedures for efficient and prompt response, analysis, documentation, ongoing management, and reporting of incidents.
use_cases: Minimizing adverse impact on business operations
Efficient and prompt incident response, analysis, documentation, management, and reporting

name: Incident Management 101.txt - ## Definitions
description: This section defines various terms and concepts related to Incident Management, which is the process of detecting, responding to, and resolving incidents or issues that impact the performance or availability of applications or systems. It covers the different stages of an incident lifecycle, from initial detection to recovery and mitigation, as well as the documentation and communication processes involved. The definitions aim to provide a common understanding of these concepts for effective incident management practices.
use_cases: Improving visibility and communication of incidents to stakeholders
Aligning incident management activities with business priorities
Maintaining service level agreements (SLAs) for application services
Documenting and analyzing incidents for root cause analysis and mitigation

name: Incident Management 101.txt - ## Categorization
description: This section explains the process of incident management, which involves categorizing incidents, prioritizing them based on severity, and following a lifecycle for detection, recovery, and root cause analysis (RCA). It covers different types of incidents, priority levels, incident notification models, triage and logging procedures, recovery steps, and RCA methodology. The section also mentions internal and external RCA documents and their respective templates and storage locations.
use_cases: Categorizing incidents as internal or production incidents
Prioritizing incidents based on severity levels (P0, P1, P2)
Detecting incidents from various sources and assigning priorities
Conducting root cause analysis (RCA) and creating internal and external RCA documents
